etymologies: Old English stīweard, from stig (probably in the sense ‘house, hall’) + weard ‘ward’. The verb dates from the early 17th century

definitions: a person who looks after the passengers on a ship, aircraft, or train and brings them meals.
shortDefinitions: person who looks after passengers on ship or train

definitions: a person responsible for supplies of food to a college, club, or other institution.
shortDefinitions: person responsible for supplies of food to institution

definitions: an official appointed to supervise arrangements or keep order at a large public event, for example a sporting event.
shortDefinitions: official appointed to supervise arrangements or keep order at large public event

definitions: a person employed to manage another's property, especially a large house or estate.
shortDefinitions: person employed to manage another's property

definitions: a person whose responsibility it is to take care of something

examples.text: farmers pride themselves on being stewards of the countryside

shortDefinitions: person whose responsibility it is to take care of something

definitions: (of an official) supervise arrangements or keep order at (a large public event)

examples.text: the event was organized and stewarded properly

shortDefinitions: supervise arrangements or keep order at

examples.text: security is found in reparticipating in community and stewarding nature
